article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: In such languages, the ergative case is typicallyMarkednessmarked(mostSalience (communication)salient), while theabsolutive caseis unmarked. New work incase theoryhas vigorously supported the idea that the ergative case identifies the agent (the intentful performer of an action) of a verb (Woolford 2004).
InKalaallisut(Greenlandic) for example, the ergative case is used to mark subjects of transitive verbs and possessors of nouns.

Nez Perce languageNez Percehas a three-way nominal case system with both ergative (-nim) andaccusative(-ne) plus an absolute (unmarked) case for intransitive subjects:hipayna qiwnthe old man arrived;hipayna wewkiyethe elk arrived;wewkiyene pexne qiwnimthe old man saw an elk.

Sahaptin languageSahaptinhas an ergative noun case (with suffix-nm) that is limited to transitive constructions only when the direct object is 1st or 2nd person:iwapatayaa mmanmthe old woman helped me;paany iwapataya mmathe old woman helped him/her (direct);pwapaataya mmayinthe old woman helped him/her (inverse).

Other languages that use the ergative case areGeorgian languageGeorgian,Chechen languageChechen, and otherCaucasian languages,Mayan languages,MixeZoque languages,Wagiman languageWagimanand otherAustralian Aboriginal languagesas well asBasque languageBasque,Burushaski,Yaghnobi languageYaghnobiandTibetic languagesTibetan.
